awd_titl_txt: Responsive, Attentive, Dialogic, and InterActive Noyce Scholars
awd_abstract_narration:
The Texas State University Noyce project, also known as Responsive, Attentive, Dialogic, and InterActive Noyce Scholars (RADIANS) project, will focus its recruitment efforts on physics, chemistry, and engineering majors, disciplines which are underrepresented in its large teacher preparation program and also represent areas of teacher shortage in US public schools. The RADIANS Project will provide scholarship support to STEM majors who seek teacher certification, resulting in 50-60 teachers over the five-year life of the project. Scholars will participate in a field-based teacher preparation program that is research-based and is collaboratively delivered by STEM and Education faculty members. The first semester of this program will be delivered onsite at an area high school that operates an innovative STEM Academy, while the second semester will consist of a full 16-week student teaching experience supervised by science education faculty from the College of Science and Engineering. During this program, faculty from the Colleges of Education and Science & Engineering will also design and deliver monthly full-day Saturday Seminars for the scholars to enhance their content knowledge and content-specific pedagogical skills, and to increase their knowledge of the latest research on STEM identity and their ability to support K-12 students' STEM identity development. Project staff will use strong partnerships with area school districts to facilitate certified scholars' employment in high-needs schools, and will coordinate with districts to provide two years of induction and mentoring. Finally, the RADIANS Project's emphasis on diversity of representation in the Learning Assistant (LA) program will result in a more diverse teaching force that can serve as advocates and positive role models for minority and economically disadvantaged students, and encourage them to pursue educational opportunities in science and teaching. 

The RADIANS Project will provide scholarship support to STEM majors seeking teacher certification, and will continue to operate the Learning Assistant (LA) initiative, one pool from which prospective teacher candidates will be recruited, launched with previous NSF support. RADIANS will support 10 to 12 scholars each year. It will investigate the long-term impact of several related interventions on the recruitment, development, and retention of science teachers and will contribute to the growing knowledge base related to STEM teacher development. The research area of STEM identity development figures into the project in two ways: (a) teacher education candidates will be taught about the latest research on high school students' STEM identity development, and (b) project personnel will study STEM teacher identity development of the teacher candidates. This will allow researchers to investigate the impact of these early experiences on the identity development of teacher candidates as they enter a teacher preparation program, progress through their teacher training, and experience their first years of classroom teaching. Potential benefits include: the recruitment of STEM majors who are experienced with research-based instruction into teaching programs will result in improved K-12 science instruction, which will lead to increases in student science achievement during the high school years and improved college and career readiness among students. Finally, the RADIANS Project's emphasis on diversity of representation has the potential to produce a more diverse teaching workforce that can serve as positive role models for students underrepresented in STEM.  Proactive encouragement of young diverse learners by a cadre of well-prepared, STEM confident, diverse teachers will positively impact participation and pursuit of STEM degrees and thus contribute to a more competitive, competent, and confident workforce.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes Report

The RADIANS Project provided scholarship support to STEM majors seeking teacher certification, and continued to operate the Physics Learning Assistant (LA) initiative launched with previous NSF support. RADIANS awarded scholarship or stipend support to 37 Scholars. Recruitment focused on physics and chemistry majors, areas of teacher shortage in US public schools.

RADIANS Scholars were 54% Male / 46% Female and 38% Hispanic / 51% White / 11% Other. During the project period, the average proportion of Hispanic students at TXST was 37%; this shows that RADIANS succeeded in recruiting Hispanic students. 57% of RADIANS Scholars participated in the Physics LA Program, which shows its importance for recruiting Scholars and for formative teaching experiences. RADIANS Scholars represented a range of teacher certification areas across physics, mathematics, chemistry, and biology, and succeeded in emphasizing representation in physics (included in 53% of various composite certifications), chemistry (21%), and mathematics (58%), as intended.

At the time of this final report, 21 Scholars have completed their teacher certification, including 12 with certifications that include physics, chemistry, or both. Scholars participated in field-based teacher preparation collaboratively delivered by STEM and Education faculty. These faculty also taught monthly full-day Saturday STEM Seminars to enhance Scholars’ content knowledge and content-specific pedagogical skills.

The project has supported development of a strongly collaborative community of Physics LAs; this community development has positively influenced the ways in which LAs engage in the activities of the physics major, outside of the activities of the LA program. Over the past six academic years, between two-thirds and three-fourths of Texas State physics graduates have had LA program participation experience. This suggests that the LA program has significantly impacted the overall physics student experience at Texas State.

Intellectual Merit:

While RADIANS was predominantly a scholarships and support program for STEM teacher candidates and newly certified STEM teachers, the PI and Co-PIs also pursued research questions related to STEM identity development of LAs and STEM teacher professional identity development. This research showed that the LA community has supported students’ physics identity development has played a critical role in supporting women of color and LGBTQ+ women in the physics major. We have published four conference proceedings papers reporting this research.

The PI team also engaged in research on the impacts of the Physics LA Program on student outcomes, and collaborated with colleagues to compare online and in-class methods of administering research-based assessments. The analysis of student outcomes included data spanning over six years, including two semesters of data prior to the implementation of the Physics LA program. Data include both learning gains on the Force Concept Inventory (FCI) and DFW rate (the fraction of students who receive grades of D or F, or who withdraw from the course). Over this time, students’ normalized gains on the FCI increased dramatically and the DFW rate was cut in half. In addition, we found that for individual faculty, FCI gains increased gradually over several semesters and DFW rates decreased gradually on the same time scale, for both novice and experienced instructors. These data suggest the need for patience with programmatic reform efforts, and for stability in instructor course assignments. The analysis of online and in-class administration of research-based assessments found equivalent student performance for the two administration methods, suggesting that instructors can save instructional time by administering assessments through secure online platforms.

Broader Impacts:

The success of the Physics LA program at Texas State is a cornerstone of the funded NSF HSI project “Building Capacity: Creating Faculty-Student Communities for Culturally Relevant Institutional Change” (“STEM Communities”, DUE-1928696, 10/2019-10/2024). This project additionally draws on research on instructional change teams; the central programmatic effort of the project is to support teams of faculty and LAs across TXST STEM departments in re-designing gateway STEM courses to incorporate active learning and LA facilitation. Courses supported by STEM Communities currently serve over 10% of the undergraduate student body at Texas State each semester, including over 30% of STEM majors, and engage around 120 undergraduate STEM majors and 25 faculty in weekly shared professional development and instructional planning.

The project team is working toward institutionalization of the Learning Assistant program and the associated changes in teaching practice in introductory courses. The synergistic activities of the STEM Communities project (NSF #1928696) have expanded LA Program components into other departments in the College of Science and Engineering, creating potential for increased recruitment into K-12 teaching in chemistry, mathematics, and biology. Our data are showing a significant decrease in the DFW rate (the percentage of students earning grades of D or F or withdrawing from the course) in classes with LA support; we are currently using these results to advocate for sustained funding from the university for the expanded LA Program.

RADIANS graduates are providing excellent science and mathematics instruction to secondary students throughout Texas and beyond.
